div.p: THE REVOLUTION IN NEW-ENGLAND JUSTIFIED, AND THE PEOPLE there VINDICATED FROM THE ASPERSIONS Ca≈øt upon them by Mr. JOHN PALMER, In his PRETENDED ANSWER to the DECLARATION Publi≈øhed by the Inhabitants of BOSTON, and the Country adjacent, on the Day when they ≈øecured their late Oppre≈ø≈øors, who acted by an ILLEGAL and ARBITRARY Commi≈ø≈øion from the late King JAMES.

TO WHICH IS ADDED, A NARRATIVE of the PROCEEDINGS OF Sir EDMOND ANDROSSE and his Accomplices. Who al≈øo acted by an ILLEGAL and ARBITRARY Commi≈ø≈øion from the late King JAMES, during his Government in NEW-ENGLAND.
By ≈øeveral GENTLEMEN who were of his COUNCIL.
Printed in the Year 1691.
BOSTON: Re-printed and ≈øold by ISAIAH THOMAS, near the MILL-BRIDGE, M,DCC,LXXIII.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: IT is not with any de≈øign or de≈øire unnece≈ø≈øarily to expo≈øe the late oppre≈ø≈øors of that good prote≈øtant people which is in New-England, that the authors of the en≈øuing vindication have publi≈øhed what is herewith emitted. But the agents lately ≈øent from thence could not be faithful to their tru≈øt, if when the people whom they repre≈øent are publicly (as well as privately) a≈øper≈øed, they ≈øhould not (either by them≈øelves, or by furni≈øhing ≈øome other with materials for ≈øuch an undertaking) vindicate tho≈øe who have been ≈øo deeply injured.

As for Mr. Palmer his account, which he calls impartial, he has wronged New-England thereby, in ≈øome other particulars be≈øides tho≈øe in≈øi≈øted on, in the ≈øub≈øequent apology. For he does endeavour
to make the world believe that the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts refu≈øed to an≈øwer to the quo-warranto pro≈øecuted again≈øt their charter: Than which mi≈ørepre≈øentation nothing can be more untrue or injurious. An account concerning that matter hath formerly (and more than once) been made public, in the which it is mo≈øt truly affirmed, That when the quo-warranto was i≈ø≈øued out again≈øt the governor and company of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts colony in New-England in the year 1683, the then king did by his declaration enjoin a few particular per≈øons to make their defence at their own charge, without any public ≈øtock; which ≈øhewed that there was a re≈øolution to take away that charter: yet the governor and company appointed an attorney to an≈øwer to the quo warranto; but the ≈øuit was let fall in the court of king's-bench, and a new ≈øuit began by ≈øcire facias in court of chancery, where time was not allowed to make defence. The former attorney for that colony brought ≈øeveral merchants to te≈øtify that in the time allowed (which was from April 16, till June 18) in was impo≈ø≈øible to have a new letter of attorney returned from New-England. The then lord keeper North replied, that no time ought to be given. So was judgment entered again≈øt them before they could po≈ø≈øibly plead for them≈øelves. By this the impartial reader may judge what ingenuity and veracity is in Mr. Palmer's account.

There is lately come forth another ≈øcandalous pamphlet, called New-England's faction di≈øcovered. The author has not put his name to it: But it is ≈øuppo≈øed to be written by a certain per≈øon
known to be a prodigy for impudence and lying. The reflection in it not only on New-England in general, but on particular per≈øons there as well as in England, are ≈øo notoriou≈øly and maliciou≈øly fal≈øe, as that it mu≈øt needs be much beneath a great mind to take notice of ≈øuch latrations, or to an≈øwer them any otherwi≈øe than with contempt. When we are treated with the buffoonry and railery of ≈øuch ungenteel pens, it is good to remember the old ≈øaying, mognum contumeliae remedium, negligentia.

As for what Mr. Palmer does in his preface in≈øinuate concerning the New-Englanders being common-wealths-men, enemies to monarchy, and to the church of England, that is ≈øuch a ≈øham as every one ≈øees through it.

There are none in the world that do more fully concur with the doctrine of the church of England contained in the 39 articles, than do the churches in New-England, as is manife≈øt from the confe≈ø≈øion of their faith publi≈øhed in the year 1680. Only as to liturgy and ceremonies they differ; for which cau≈øe alone it was that they, or their fathers, tran≈øported them≈øelves into that American de≈øert, as being de≈øirous to wor≈øhip God in that way which they thought was mo≈øt according to the ≈øcriptures. The platform of church di≈øcipline con≈øented unto by the elders and me≈ø≈øengers of the churches a≈ø≈øembled in a general ≈øynod at Cambridge in New-England in the year 1647, ≈øheweth that they are as to church government for the congregational way. The judiciou≈øly learned Mr. Philip Nye has long ≈øince evinced that no form of church-government (no not that which is epi≈øcopal) is more con≈øi≈øtent with monarchy,
or with the king's ≈øupremacy, than that of the way-congregational, which ≈øome will needs call independent. But there are a ≈øort of men, who call tho≈øe that are for Engli≈øh liberties, and that rejoice in the government of their pre≈øent maje≈øties, king William and queen Mary, by the name of republicans, and repre≈øent all ≈øuch as enemies of monarchy and of the church. It is not our ≈øingle opinion only, but we can ≈øpeak it on the behalf of the generality of their maje≈øties ≈øubjects in New-England, that they believe (without any diminution to the glory of our former princes) the Engli≈øh nation was never ≈øo happy in a king, or in a queen, as at this day. And the God of heaven, who has ≈øet them on the throne of the≈øe kingdoms, grant them long and pro≈øperou≈øly to reign.

div.head: THE REVOLUTION IN NEW-ENGLAND JUSTIFIED.
div.p: THE doctrine of pa≈ø≈øive obedience and non-re≈øi≈øtance, which a ≈øort of men did of late, when they thought the world would never change, cry up as divine truth, is by means of the happy revolution in the≈øe nations, exploded, and the a≈ø≈øertors of it become ridiculous.

No man does really approve of the revolution in England, but mu≈øt ju≈øtify that in New-England al≈øo; for the latter was effected in compliance with the former, neither was there any de≈øign among the people in New-England to rea≈ø≈øume their ancient charter-government, until his pre≈øent maje≈øty's intended de≈øcent into England, to re≈øcue the nation from ≈ølavery as well as popery, was known to them (for indeed to have attempted it before that would have been madne≈øs.) They
con≈øidered that the men then u≈øurping government in New-England were king James's creatures, who had invaded both the liberty and property of Engli≈øh prote≈øtants after ≈øuch a manner as perhaps the like was never known in any part of the world where the Engli≈øh nation has any government; and the commi≈ø≈øion which they had obtained from the late king James was more illegal and arbitrary, than that granted to Dudley and Emp≈øon by king Henry 7th. Or than it may be was ever before given to any by king James him≈øelf, or by any one that ever ≈øwayed the Engli≈øh ≈øcepter, which was a grievance intolerable; and yet they de≈øired not to make them≈øelves judges in a ca≈øe which ≈øo nearly concerned them, but in≈øtead of har≈øher treatment of tho≈øe who had tyrannized over them, they only ≈øecured them that they might not betray that country into the hands of the late king, or of king Lewis, which they had rea≈øon enough to believe (con≈øidering their characters and di≈øpo≈øitions) they were inclined to do. They de≈øigned not to revenge them≈øelves on their enemies, which they could as ea≈øily have done as a thou≈øand men are able to kill one, and therefore when they ≈øecured their per≈øons, they declared (as in their declaration printed at Bo≈øton in New-England is to be ≈øeen) that they would leave it to the king and parliament of England, to inflict what puni≈øhment they ≈øhould think meet for ≈øuch criminals. Their ≈øeizing and ≈øecuring the governor, was no more than was done in England, at Hull, Dover, Plymouth, &c. that ≈øuch a man as Mr. John Palmer ≈øhould exclaim again≈øt it, is not to be wondered at, ≈øeeing he was one of the governor's tools, being of his council, made a judge by him, and too much concerned in ≈øome illegal and arbitrary proceedings; but his confidence is wonderful, that he ≈øhould publi≈øh in print that neither him≈øelf nor ≈øir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe, nor others of them who had been ≈øecured by the people in New-England, had any crimes laid to their charge, whereas the fore≈øaid declaration emitted the very day they were ≈øecured, doth plainly ≈øet forth their crimes. And in the preface of his book he hath the≈øe words; viz.
We appeared at the council-board where the wor≈øt of our enemies, even the very men who had ≈øo unju≈øtly impri≈øoned and detained us, had nothing to ≈øay or object again≈øt us.‚Äî

By the≈øe enemies he ≈øpeaks of, we ≈øuppo≈øe he means tho≈øe who were lately ≈øent as agents from Bo≈øton in New-England; he hath therefore nece≈ø≈øitated us to inform the world, that the following objections (though not by his enemies, yet) by tho≈øe agents pre≈øented at the council-board.

div.head: Matters objected again≈øt Sir EDMUND ANDROSSE, Mr. JOSEPH DUDLEY, Mr. PALMER, Mr. RANDOLPH, Mr. WEST, Mr. GRAHAM, Mr. FAREWELL, Mr. SHERLOCK and others, as occa≈øions of their impri≈øonment in New-England.
div.p: 1. IT is objected again≈øt Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe, that he being governor of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts colony, after notice of his pre≈øent Maje≈øty's intention to land in England, i≈ø≈øued out a proclamation, requiring all per≈øons to oppo≈øe any de≈øcent of ≈øuch as might be authorized by him, endeavoured to ≈øtifle the news of his landing, and cau≈øed him that brought this king's declaration thither to be impri≈øoned, as bringing a ≈øeditious and trea≈øonable paper.

2. That in the time of his government, he without form or colour of legal authority made laws de≈øtructive of the liberty of the people, impo≈øed and levied taxes, threatened and impri≈øoned them that would not be a≈ø≈øi≈øting to the illegal levies, denied that they had any property in their lands without patents from him, and during the time of actual war with the Indians, he did ≈øupply them with amunition, and ≈øeveral Indians declared, that they were incouraged by him to make war upon the Engli≈øh, and he di≈øcountenanced making defence again≈øt the Indians.

3. As to all the other per≈øons impri≈øoned, they were accomplices and confederates with Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe, and particularly Mr. Dudley, Mr. Randolph, and Mr. Palmer were of his council, and joined with him in his arbitrary laws and impo≈øitions, and in threatening and in puni≈øhing them who would not comply. Mr. We≈øt was his ≈øecretary, and guilty of great extortion, and gave out words which ≈øhewed him≈øelf no friend to the Engli≈øh. Mr. Graham was his attorney at one time, and Mr. Farewell at another, both concerned in illegal proceedings de≈øtructive of the property of the ≈øubject. Mr. Farewell pro≈øecuted them who refu≈øed to comply with the illegal levies, and Mr. Graham brought ≈øeveral writs of intru≈øion again≈øt men for their own land, and Mr. Sherlock, another per≈øon impri≈øoned, though not named in the order, acted there for ≈øome years as an high ≈øheriff, though he was a ≈øtranger in the country, and had no e≈øtate there, during his ≈øherievalty he impannelled juries of ≈øtrangers, who had no freehold in that country, and extorted unrea≈øonable fees.

The≈øe particulars were not only pre≈øented at the council-board, but there read before the right honorable the lords of the committee of foreign plantations on April 17, 1690. when Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe, Mr. Palmer, and the re≈øt concerned were pre≈øent, and owned that they had received copies thereof from Mr. Blaithwaite. It is true that the paper then read was not ≈øigned by the agents afore≈øaid, for which rea≈øon (as we under≈øtand, nor could it rationally be otherwi≈øe expected) the matter was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed without an hearing; neverthele≈øs the gentlemen who appeared as council for the New-England agents, declared, that they were ready to prove every article of the objections; which ≈øhall now be done.

1. That Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe, with others whom the people in New-England ≈øeized, and ≈øecured did, after notice of his pre≈øent maje≈øty's intended de≈øcent into England to deliver the nation from popery and arbitrary power, to their utmo≈øt oppo≈øe that glorious de≈øign, is manife≈øt by the proclamation printed and publi≈øhed in New-England, Jan. 10, 1688, ≈øigned by Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe and his deputy ≈øecretary John We≈øt, in which King James's proclamation of October 16, 1688, is recited and referred unto. Sir Edmund's proclamation begins thus; Whereas his maje≈øty has been graciou≈øly plea≈øed by his royal letter bearing date the 16th of October la≈øt pa≈øt, to ≈øignify that he hath undoubted advice that a great and ≈øudden inva≈øion from Holland, with an armed force of foreigners and ≈øtrangers will be ≈øpeedily made in an ho≈øtile manner upon his maje≈øty's kingdom of England, and that although ≈øome fal≈øe pretences relating to liberty, property, and religion,' &c. And then he concludes thus‚Äî 'All which it is his maje≈øty's plea≈øure ≈øhould be made known in the mo≈øt public manner to his loving ≈øubjects within this his territory and dominion of New-England, that they may be the better prepared to re≈øi≈øt any attempts that may be made by his maje≈øty's enemies in the≈øe parts, I do therefore hereby charge and command all officers civil and military, and all other his maje≈øty's loving ≈øubjects within this his territory and dominion afore≈øaid, to be vigilant and careful in their re≈øpective places and ≈øtations, and that upon the approach of any fleet or foreign force, they be in readine≈øs, and u≈øe their utmo≈øt endeavours to hinder any landing or inva≈øion that may be intended to be made within the ≈øame.

2. And that they u≈øed all imaginable endeavours to ≈øtifle the news of the prince's landing in England, appears not only from the te≈øtimony of the people there, and from the letters of tho≈øe now in government at Bo≈øton, but from the depo≈øition
of Mr. John Win≈ølow, who affirms that being in Nevis in February 1688, a ≈øhip arrived there from England with the prince of Orange's declaration, and intelligence of the happy change of affairs in England, which he knew would be welcome news in New-England, and therefore was at the charge to procure a written copy of that princely declaration with which he arrived at Bo≈øton about a fortnight before the revolution there. He concealed the declaration, from Sir Edmund, becau≈øe he believed if it came into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, he would keep the people in ignorance concerning it; but intimation being given that Mr. Win≈ølow had brought with him the declaration, he was therefore committed to pri≈øon (though he offered two thou≈øand pounds bail) for bringing into the country a trea≈øonable paper. For the ≈øatisfaction of ≈øuch as are willing to be informed in this matter, Mr. Win≈ølow's te≈øtimony as it was given upon oath before a magi≈øtrate in New-England ≈øhall be here in≈øerted. It is as follows, viz.

JOHN WINSLOW, aged twenty-four years, or thereabouts, te≈øtifieth and ≈øaith, that he being in Nevis, ≈øome time in February la≈øt pa≈øt, there came in a ≈øhip from ≈øome part of England with the prince of Orange's declarations, and brought news al≈øo of his happy proceedings in England with his entrance there, which was very welcome news to me, and I knew it would be ≈øo to the re≈øt of the people in New-England; and I being bound thither, and very willing to carry ≈øuch good news with me, gave four ≈øhillings ≈øix pence for the ≈øaid declarations, on purpo≈øe to let the people in New-England under≈øtand what a ≈øpeedy deliverance they might expect from arbitrary power. We arrived at Bo≈øton harbour the fourth day of April following, and as ≈øoon as I came home to my hou≈øe, Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe under≈øtanding I brought the prince's declarations with me, ≈øent the ≈øheriff to me; ≈øo I went along with him to the governor's hou≈øe, and as ≈øoon as I came in, he a≈øked me why I did not come and tell him the news. I told him I thought it not my duty, neither was it cu≈øtomary for any pa≈ø≈øenger to go to the governor when the ma≈øter of the ≈øhip had been with him before, and told him the news; he a≈øked me where the declarations I brought with me were, I told him I could not tell, being afraid to let him have them, becau≈øe he would not let the people know any news. He told me I was a ≈øaucy fellow, and bid the ≈øheriff carry me away to the ju≈øtices of the peace, and as we were going, I told the ≈øheriff, I would choo≈øe my ju≈øtice, he told me, no, I mu≈øt go before doctor Bullivant,
one pickt on purpo≈øe (as I judged) for the bu≈øine≈øs; well I told him, I did not care who I went before, for I knew my cau≈øe good, ≈øo ≈øoon as I came in, two more of the ju≈øtices dropt in, Charles Lidget and Francis Foxcroft, ≈øuch as the former, fit for the purpo≈øe, ≈øo they a≈øked me for my papers, I told them I would not let them have them by rea≈øon they kept all the news from the people, ≈øo when they ≈øaw they could not get what I bought with my money, they ≈øent me to pri≈øon for bringing traiterous and trea≈øonable libels and papers of news, notwith≈øtanding, I offered them ≈øecurity to the value of two thou≈øand pounds.

div.p: By the≈øe things it appears that it was ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary for the people in New-England to ≈øeize Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe and his accomplices, that ≈øo they might ≈øecure that territory for their pre≈øent maje≈øties king William and queen Mary.

3. That Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe, &c. did make laws de≈øtructive to the liberty of the ≈øubjects, is notoriou≈øly known, for they made what laws they plea≈øed without any con≈øent of the people, either by them≈øelves or repre≈øentatives, which is indeed to de≈øtroy the fundamentals of the Engli≈øh and to erect a French government. We cannot learn that the like was ever practi≈øed in any place where the Engli≈øh are planters, but only where Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe hath been governor: For whereas in New-England by con≈øtant u≈øage under their charter government, the inhabitants of each town did a≈ø≈øemble as occa≈øion offered to con≈øider of what might conduce to the welfare of their re≈øpective towns, the relief of the poor, or the like, Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe, with a few of his council, made a law prohibiting any town-meeting except once a year, viz. on the third Monday in May. The inhabitants of the country were ≈øtartled at this law, as being apprehen≈øive the de≈øign of it was to prevent the people in every town from meeting to make complaints of their grievances. And whereas by con≈øtant u≈øage any per≈øon might remove out of the country at his plea≈øure, a law was made that no man ≈øhould do ≈øo without the governor's leave. And all fi≈øhing boats, coa≈øters, &c. were to enter into a thou≈øand pounds bond, whereby fees were rai≈øed for him≈øelf and creatures. This law could not pa≈øs at Bo≈øton, becau≈øe many of Sir Edmund's council there oppo≈øed it; but then a juncto of them meeting at New-York, pa≈ø≈øed it; and after that law was made, how ≈øhould any di≈ø≈øatisfied per≈øons ever obtain
liberty to go for England to complain of their being oppre≈ø≈øed by arbitrary governors?

4. But be≈øides all this, they made laws for the levying monies without the con≈øent of the people either by them≈øelves or by an a≈ø≈øembly; for in order to the ≈øupporting their own government, they did by an act bearing date March 3, 1686, rai≈øe con≈øiderable ≈øums of money on the king's ≈øubjects in that part of his dominions, viz. a penny in the pound on all e≈øtates per≈øonal or real, twenty pence per head as poll money, a penny in the pound for goods imported, be≈øides an exci≈øe on wine, rum and other liquors.

It hath indeed been pleaded that all this was but what the laws of the country before the change of the government did allow. But this is vainly pretended, for there was no ≈øuch law in force at the time when the≈øe ≈øums were levied, the former laws which did authorize it, were repealed October 10, 1683, ≈øome years before Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe and his accomplices had invaded the rights and liberties of the people there. Moreover, in tho≈øe parts of the country where there were never any ≈øuch laws in force, particularly in Plymouth colony, this money was levied, which they heavily complained of. Yet further, in another act dated Feb. 15, 1687, they did without any colour of ancient law make an additional duty of impo≈øt and exci≈øe, which rai≈øed the duty, ≈øome ten ≈øhillings, ≈øome twenty ≈øhillings per pipe on wines, and ≈øo on other things. Nay they levied monies on Connecticut colony contrary to their charter, which was never vacated, than which nothing more illegal and arbitrary could have been perpetrated by them.

5. They did not only act according to the≈øe illegal taxes, but they did inflict ≈øevere puni≈øhment on tho≈øe true Engli≈øh men who did oppo≈øe their arbitrary proceedings, as ≈øhall be made to appear in many in≈øtances. When the inhabitants of Ip≈øwich in New-England were required to choo≈øe a commi≈ø≈øioner to tax that town, ≈øome principal per≈øons there that could not comply with what was demanded of them, did mode≈øtly give their rea≈øons, for which they were committed to goal, as guilty of high mi≈ødemeanours, and denied an habeus corpus, and were obliged to an≈øwer it at a court of oyer and terminer at Bo≈øton. And that they might be ≈øure to be found guilty, jurors were picked of ≈øuch as were no freeholders, nay of ≈øtrangers; the pri≈øoners pleading the privilege of Engli≈øhmen not to be taxed without their own con≈øent, they were told that the laws of England would not follow them to the end of the earth, they meant the privileges of the Engli≈øh law, for the penalties they re≈øolved ≈øhould follow
them quo jure qu√¢que injuri√¢. And why ≈øhould they in≈øi≈øt on, and talk of the privileges of Engli≈øhmen, when it had been declared in the governor's council, that the king's ≈øubjects in New-England did not differ much from ≈ølaves, and that the only difference was, that they were not bought and ≈øold? But to go on with the matter before us; in as much as the pri≈øoners mentioned had a≈ø≈øerted their Engli≈øh liberties, they were ≈øeverely handled, not only impri≈øoned for ≈øeveral weeks, but fined and bound to their good behaviour; Mr. John Wi≈øe was fined fifty pounds be≈øides co≈øts of court, deprived of the means of his ≈øub≈øi≈øtance, and gave a thou≈øand pounds bond for good behavior. And Mr. John Appleton was fined fifty pounds and to give a thou≈øand pounds bond for good behavior, and moreover declared incapable to bear office, be≈øides unrea≈øonable fees. After the ≈øame manner did they proceed with ≈øeveral others belonging to Ip≈øwich. Likewi≈øe the towns men of Rowley, Sali≈øbury, Andover, &c. had the ≈øame mea≈øure. And the king's ≈øubjects were not only oppre≈ø≈øed thus in the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts colony, but in Plymouth. For when Shadrach Wild boar the town-clerk of Taunton in New-England did, with the con≈øent of the town, ≈øign a mode≈øt paper ≈øignifying their not being free to rai≈øe money on the inhabitants without their own con≈øent by an a≈ø≈øembly, the hone≈øt man was for this committed clo≈øe pri≈øoner, and after that puni≈øhed with a fine of twenty marks and three months impri≈øonment, and bound to find ≈øureties by recognizance to appear the next court, and to be of the good behaviour. As to the matter of fact, the per≈øons concerned in the≈øe illegal and arbitrary judgments will not have the face to deny them; if they do, there are affidavits now in London which will evince what hath been related when ever there ≈øhall be occa≈øion for it.

It is a vanity in Mr. Palmer, to think that he hath an≈øwered this by affirming, but not proving, that the Ip≈øwich men a≈ø≈øembled them≈øelves in a riotous manner; for that ≈øaying of his is very fal≈øe. The world knows that New-England is not the only place where hone≈øt men have in the≈øe late days been proceeded again≈øt as guilty of riots, when they never de≈øerved ≈øuch a cen≈øure any more than the≈øe accu≈øed by Mr. Palmer. But the truth of what hath been thus far related is confirmed by the following affidavits.

div.head: Complaints of great wrongs done under the ill government of Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe governor in New-England, in the year 1687.
div.p:
We John Wi≈øe, John Andrews, ≈øenior, Robert Kin≈øman, William Goodhue, junior, all of Ip≈øwich in New-England, in
the county of E≈ø≈øex, about the 22d day of Augu≈øt, in the year above named, were with ≈øeveral principal inhabitants of the town of Ip≈øwich met at Mr. John Appleton's, and there di≈øcour≈øed and concluded that it was not the town's duty any way to a≈ø≈øi≈øt that ill method of rai≈øing money without a general a≈ø≈øembly, which was apparently intended by above≈øaid Sir Edmund and his council, as witne≈øs a late act i≈ø≈øued out by them for ≈øuch a purpo≈øe. The next day in a general town-meeting of the inhabitants of Ip≈øwich; we the above named John Wi≈øe, John Andrews, Robert Kin≈øman, William Goodhue with the re≈øt of the town then met (none contradicting) gave our a≈ø≈øent to the vote then made.

The ground of our trouble, our crime was the copy tran≈ømitted to the council, viz. At a legal town meeting Augu≈øt 23. A≈ø≈øembled by virtue of an order from John U≈øher, E≈øq trea≈øurer for choo≈øing a commi≈ø≈øioner to join with the ≈øelect-men, to a≈ø≈øe≈øs the inhabitants according to an act of his excellency the governor and council for laying of rates; the town then con≈øidering that the ≈øaid act doth infringe their liberty, as free born Engli≈øh ≈øubjects of his maje≈øty by interfering with the ≈øtatute laws of the land, by which it was enacted that no taxes ≈øhould be levied upon the ≈øubjects without con≈øent of an a≈ø≈øembly cho≈øen by the freeholders for a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing of the ≈øame, they do therefore vote that they are not willing to choo≈øe a commi≈ø≈øioner for ≈øuch an end without ≈øaid privilege; and moreover con≈øent not that the ≈øelect-men do proceed to lay any ≈øuch rate until it be appointed by a general a≈ø≈øembly concurring with the governor and council. We the complainants with Mr. John Appleton and Thomas French all of Ip≈øwich were brought to an≈øwer for the ≈øaid vote out of our own county, thirty or forty miles into Suffolk, and in Bo≈øton kept in goal, only for contempt and high mi≈ødemeanors as our mitimus ≈øpecifies, and upon demand, denied the privilege of an habeas corpus, and from pri≈øon over-ruled to an≈øwer at a court of eyer and terminer in Bo≈øton afore≈øaid. Our judges were Mr. Jo≈øeph Dudley of Roxbury in Suffolk in New-England, Mr. Stoughton of Dorche≈øter, John U≈øher of Bo≈øton, trea≈øurer, and Edward Randolph. He that officiates as clerk and attorney in the ca≈øe is George Farewell.

The jurors only twelve men and mo≈øt of them (as is ≈øaid) non-freeholders of any land in the colony, ≈øome of them ≈øtrangers and foreigners, gathered up (as we ≈øuppo≈øe) to ≈øerve the pre≈øent turn. In our defence was pleaded the repeal of the law of a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øment upon the place. Al≈øo the
Magna Charta of England, and the ≈øtatute laws that ≈øecure the ≈øubjects properties and e≈øtates, &c. To which was replied by one of the judges, the re≈øt by ≈øilence a≈ø≈øenting, that we mu≈øt not think the laws of England follow us to the ends of the earth, or whether we went. And the ≈øame per≈øon (John Wi≈øe above≈øaid te≈øtifies) declared in open council upon examination of ≈øaid Wi≈øe; Mr. Wi≈øe you have no more privileges left you, than not to be ≈øold for ≈ølaves, and no man in council contradicted. By ≈øuch laws our trial and trouble began and ended. Mr. Dudley afore≈øaid chief judge, to clo≈øe up the debate and trial, trims up a ≈øpeech that plea≈øed him≈øelf (we ≈øuppo≈øe) more than the people. Among many other remarkable pa≈ø≈øages, to this purpo≈øe, he be≈øpeaks the jury's obedience, who (we ≈øuppo≈øe) were very well preinclined, viz. I am glad, ≈øays he, there be ≈øo many worthy gentlemen of the jury ≈øo capable to do the king ≈øervice, and we expect a good verdict from you, ≈øeeing the matter hath been ≈øo ≈øufficiently proved again≈øt the criminals. Note, the evidence in the ca≈øe as to the ≈øub≈øtance of it, was that we too boldly endeavoured to per≈øuade our≈øelves we were Engli≈øh men, and under privileges; and that we were all ≈øix of us afore≈øaid at the town meeting of Ip≈øwich afore≈øaid, and as the witne≈øs ≈øuppo≈øed, we a≈ø≈øented to the fore≈øaid vote, and al≈øo that John Wi≈øe made a ≈øpeech at the ≈øame time, and ≈øaid we had a good God, and a good king, and ≈øhould do well to ≈øtand for our privileges‚ÄîJury returns us all ≈øix guilty, being all involved in the ≈øame information. We were remanded from verdict to pri≈øon, and there kept one and twenty days for judgment. There with Mr. Dudley's approbation, as judge Stoughton ≈øaid, this ≈øentence was pa≈ø≈øed, viz.
John Wi≈øe, ≈øu≈øpended from the mini≈øterial functions, fine fifty pound, money, pay co≈øt, a thou≈øand pound bond for the good behaviour one year.
John Appleton not to bear office, fine 50.l money, pay co≈øt, a thou≈øand pound for the good behavior one year.
John Andrews not to bear office, fine 30l. money, pay co≈øt, five hundred pound bond for the good behavior one year.
Robert Kin≈øman not to bear office, fine 20l. money, pay co≈øt, five hundred pound bond for the good behavior one year.
William Goodhue not to bear office, fine 20l. money, pay co≈øt, five hundred pound bond for the good behavior one year.
Thomas French not to bear office, fine 15l. money, pay co≈øt, five hundred pound bond for the good behaviour one year.

The total fees of this ca≈øe upon one ≈øingle information demanded by Farewell above≈øaid, amount to about a hundred and one pound ≈øeventeen ≈øhillings, who demanded of us ≈øingly about ≈øixteen pound nineteen ≈øhillings ≈øix pence, the co≈øt of pro≈øecution, the fines added make up this, viz. Two hundred eighty and ≈øix pounds ≈øeventeen ≈øhillings, money.

To all which we may add a large account of other fees of me≈ø≈øengers, pri≈øon charges, money for bonds and tran≈øcripts of records, exhau≈øted by tho≈øe ill men one way and another to the value of three or four≈øcore pounds, be≈øides our expence of time and impri≈øonment.

We judge the total charge for one ca≈øe and trial under one ≈øingle information involving us ≈øix men above≈øaid in expence of time and monies of us and our relations for our nece≈ø≈øary ≈øuccour and ≈øupport to amount to more, but no le≈øs than 400l. money.
Too tedious to illu≈øtrate more amply at this time, and ≈øo we conclude. John Wi≈øe, John Andrews ≈øenior, William Goodhue, junior, Thomas French, the≈øe four per≈øons named, and Robert Kin≈øman.

The≈øe four per≈øons fir≈øt named appeared the twentieth day of December, and Robert Kin≈øman appeared the one and twentieth day of December, 1689, and gave in their te≈øtimony upon oath before me Samuel Appleton a≈ø≈øi≈øtant for the colony of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts in New-England.

6. That tho≈øe who were in confederacy with Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe for the enriching them≈øelves on the ruins of New-England, did invade the property as well as liberty of the ≈øubject, is in the next place to be cleared, and we tru≈øt will be made out beyond di≈øpute. When they little imagined that there ≈øhould ever be ≈øuch a revolution in England as that which by means of his pre≈øent maje≈øty this nation is ble≈øt with, they feared not to declare their ≈øentiments to the inexpre≈ø≈øible exa≈øperation of the people whom they were then domineering over. They gave out, that now their charter was gone, all their lands were the king's, that them≈øelves did repre≈øent the king, and that therefore men that would have any legal title to their lands mu≈øt take patents of them, on ≈øuch terms as they ≈øhould ≈øee meet to impo≈øe. What people that had the ≈øpirits of Engli≈øhmen, could endure this? That when they had at va≈øt charges of their own conquered a wilderne≈øs, and
been in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of their e≈øtates forty, nay ≈øixty years, that now a parcel of ≈øtrangers, ≈øome of them indigent enough, mu≈øt come and inherit all that the people now in New-England and their fathers before them, had laboured for! Let the whole nation judge, whether the≈øe men were not driving on a French de≈øign, and had not fairly erected a French government. And that our adver≈øaries may not in≈øult and ≈øay, the≈øe are words without proof, we ≈øhall here ≈øubjoin the te≈øtimonies of the reverend Mr. Higgin≈øon, and ≈øeveral other worthy per≈øons, given in upon oath, concerning this matter.

Being called by tho≈øe in pre≈øent authority to give my te≈øtimony to the di≈øcour≈øe between Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe and my≈øelf, when he came from the Indian war, as he pa≈ø≈øed through Salem going for Bo≈øton in March 1688-9, I cannot refu≈øe it, and therefore declare as followeth, what was the ≈øub≈øtance of that di≈øcour≈øe. Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe then governor being acompanied with the attorney-general Graham, ≈øecretary We≈øt, judge Palmer, the room being al≈øo full of other people, mo≈øt of them his attendants, he was plea≈øed to tell me, he would have my judgment about this que≈øtion; Whether all the lands in New-England were not the king's? I told him I was ≈øurprized with ≈øuch a que≈øtion, and was not willing to ≈øpeak to it; that being a mini≈øter, if it was a que≈øtion about a matter of religion, I ≈øhould not be aver≈øe, but this being a ≈øtate matter, I did not look upon it as proper for me to declare my mind in it, therefore entreated again and again that I might be excu≈øed. Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe replied and urged me with much importunity, ≈øaying, Becau≈øe you are a mini≈øter, therefore we de≈øire to know your judgment in it, then I told him, if I mu≈øt ≈øpeak to it, I would only ≈øpeak as a mini≈øter from ≈øcripture and rea≈øon, not medling with the law. He ≈øaid, the king's attorney was pre≈øent there to inform what was law. I then ≈øaid, I did not under≈øtand that the lands of New-England were the king's, but the king's ≈øubjects, who had for more than ≈øixty years had the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and u≈øe of them by a twofold right warranted by the word of God. 1. By a right of ju≈øt occupation from the grand charter in Gene≈øis 1≈øt and 9th chapters, whereby God gave the earth to the ≈øons of Adam and Noah, to be ≈øubdued and repleni≈øhed. 2. By a right of purcha≈øe from the Indians, who were native inhabitants, and had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the land before the Engli≈øh came hither, and that having lived here ≈øixty years. I did certainly know that from the beginning of the≈øe plantations our fathers entered upon the land, partly
as a wilderne≈øs and Vacuum Domicilium, and partly by the con≈øent of the Indians, and therefore care was taken to treat with them, and to gain their con≈øent, giving them ≈øuch a valuable con≈øideration as was to their ≈øatisfaction, and this I told them I had the more certain knowledge of, becau≈øe having learned the Indian language in my younger time, I was at ≈øeveral times made u≈øe of by the government, and by divers particular plantations as an interpreter in treating with the Indians about their lands, which being done and agreed on, the ≈øeveral town≈øhips and proportions of lands of particular men were ordered and ≈øettled by the government of the country, and therefore I did believe that the lands of New-England were the ≈øubjects properties, and not the king's lands. Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe and the re≈øt replied, that the lands were the king's, and that he gave the lands within ≈øuch limits to his ≈øubjects by a charter upon ≈øuch conditions as were not performed, and therefore all the lands of New-England have returned to the king, and that the attorney general then pre≈øent could tell what was law, who ≈øpake divers things to the ≈øame purpo≈øe as Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe had done, ≈ølighting what I had ≈øaid, and vilifying the Indian title, ≈øaying, they were brutes, &c. and if we had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed and u≈øed the land, they ≈øaid we were the king's ≈øubjects, and what lands the king's ≈øubjects have, they are the king's, and one of them u≈øed ≈øuch an expre≈ø≈øion, where-ever an Engli≈øhman ≈øets his foot, all that he hath is the king's, and more to the ≈øame purpo≈øe. I told them that ≈øo far as I under≈øtood, we received only the right and power of government from the king's charter within ≈øuch limits and bounds, but the right of the land and ≈øoil we had received from God according to his grand charter to the ≈øons of Adam and Noah, and with the con≈øent of the native inhabitants as I had expre≈ø≈øed before. They ≈øtill in≈øi≈øted on the king's right to the land as before, whereupon I told them, I had heard it was a ≈øtanding principle in law and rea≈øon, nil dat qui non habet; and from thence I propounded this argument, he that hath no right, can give no right to another, but the king had no right to the lands of America before the Engli≈øh came hither, therefore he could give no right to them. I told them, I knew not of any that could be pleaded but from a Popi≈øh principle, that chri≈øtians have a right to the lands of heathen, upon which the Pope as the head of the chri≈øtians had given the We≈øt-Indies to the king of Spain, but this was di≈øowned by all prote≈øtants. Therefore I left it to them to affirm and prove
the king's title. They replied and in≈øi≈øted much upon that, that the king had a right by his ≈øubjects coming and taking po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of this land. And at la≈øt Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe ≈øaid with indignation, either you are ≈øubjects or you are rebels, intimating, as I under≈øtood him, according to the whole ≈øcope and tendency of his ≈øpeeches and actions, that if we would not yield all the lands of New-England to be the king's, ≈øo as to take patents for lands, and to pay rent for the ≈øame, then we ≈øhould not be accounted ≈øubjects but rebels, and treated accordingly. There were many other various replies and an≈øwers on both ≈øides, but this is the ≈øum and ≈øub≈øtance of that di≈øcour≈øe.
John Higgin≈øon, mini≈øter in Salem, per≈øonally appeared before me, December, 24, 1689, and made oath to the truth of the above≈øaid evidence.
Captain Stephen Seawall of Salem appeared before me, December 24, 1689, and made oath to the truth of the above≈øaid evidence.

Jo≈øeph Lynde of Charle≈øtown in the county of Middle≈øex in New-England, being fifty-three years of age, te≈øtifieth and ≈øaith, that in the year 1687, Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe then governor of New-England did enquire of him the ≈øaid Lynde what title he had to his lands, who ≈øhewed him many deeds for land that he the ≈øaid Lynde po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and particularly for land that the ≈øaid Lynde was certainly informed would quickly be given away from him, if he did not u≈øe means to obtain a patent for it. The deed being con≈øidered by Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe, he ≈øaid it was worded well, and recorded according to New-England cu≈øtom or words to the ≈øame purpo≈øe. He further enquired how the title was derived, he the ≈øaid Lynde told him, that he bought it of, had it of, his father-in-law in marriage with his wife, and his ≈øaid father from Charle≈øtown, and the ≈øaid town from the general court grant of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay, and al≈øo by purcha≈øe from the natives, and he ≈øaid, my title were nothing worth if that were all.
At another time after ≈øhewing him an Indian deed for land, he ≈øaid, that their hand was no more worth than a ≈øcratch of a bear's paw, under-valuing all my titles, though every way legal under our former charter government. I then petitioned for a patent for my whole e≈øtate, but Mr. We≈øt deputy ≈øecretary told me I mu≈øt have ≈øo many patents as there were counties that I had parcels of land in, if not towns, finding the thing ≈øo chargeable and difficult I delayed, upon which I had a writ of intru≈øion ≈øerved upon me in the beginning of the ≈øummer 1688, the copy whereof is in the Charle≈øtown men's complaint, and was at the ≈øame time with that of Mr. James Ru≈ø≈øell's, Mr. Seawall's and Mr. Shrimpton's, it being for the ≈øame land in part that I ≈øhewed my title unto Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe as above, being my≈øelf and tho≈øe I derived it from po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, inclo≈øed, and improved for about fifty years, at which time I gave Mr. Graham attorney general three pounds in money, promi≈øing that if he would let the action fall I would pay court charges, and give him ten pound, when I had a patent compleated for that ≈ømall parcel of land, that ≈øaid writ was ≈øerved upon me for, which I did becau≈øe a Quaker that had the promi≈øe of it from the governor, as I was informed in the governor's pre≈øence ≈øhould not have it from me, the ≈øaid Lynde, having about ≈øeven acres more in the ≈øame common field or pa≈øture, about a mile from his forty-nine acres near unto the land that the ≈øaid governor gave unto Mr. Charles Lidget, of divers of my neighbours which I concluded mu≈øt go the ≈øame way theirs went and therefore though de≈øired to be patenteed by the ≈øaid Lynde with the forty-nine acres, he could not obtain a grant for it. About the ≈øame time Mr. Graham attorney general a≈øked the ≈øaid Lynde what he would do about the re≈øt of his land, telling him the ≈øaid Lynde that he would meet with the like trouble about all the re≈øt of his lands that he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and were it not for the governor's going to New-York at this time, there would be a writ of intru≈øion again≈øt every man in the colony of any con≈øiderable e≈øtate, or as many as a cart could hold, and for the poorer ≈øort of people ≈øaid Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe would take other mea≈øures, or words to the ≈øame purpo≈øe. The ≈øaid Lynde further ≈øaith, That after judgments obtained for ≈ømall wrongs done him, triable by their own laws before a ju≈øtice of the peace, from whom they allowed no appeals in ≈ømall cau≈øes, he was forced out of his own county by writs of fal≈øe judgment; and although at the fir≈øt ≈øuperiour court in Suffolk, the thing was ≈øo far oppo≈øed by judge Stoughton as illegal, as that it was put by,
yet the next term by judge Dudley and judge Palmer, the ≈øaid Lynde was forced to an≈øwer George Farewell attorney afore≈øaid, then ≈øaying in open court in Charle≈øtown, that all cau≈øes mu≈øt be brought to Bo≈øton in Suffolk, becau≈øe there was not hone≈øt men enough in Middle≈øex to make a jury to ≈øerve their turns, or words to that purpo≈øe; nor did Suffolk, as appeared by their practice, for they made u≈øe of non-re≈øidents in divers ca≈øes there. I mention not any damage though it is great, but to the truth above written I the ≈øaid Lynde do ≈øet my hand.

closer.signed: Juratus coram me, JOHN SMITH, A≈ø≈øi≈øtant.

div.p: And that the practices of the≈øe men have been according to their principles, de≈øtructive to the property of the ≈øubject, is now to be declared. It is a thing too well known to be denied, that ≈øome of Sir Edmund's council begged (if they had not had ≈øecret encouragement no man believes they would have done ≈øo) tho≈øe lands which are called the commons belonging to ≈øeveral town≈øhips, whereby Plymouth, Lynn, Cambridge, Rhode-I≈øland, &c. would have been ruinated, had the≈øe men's projects taken effect. And not only the commons belonging to towns, but tho≈øe lands which were the property of ≈øeveral particular per≈øons in Charle≈øtown, were granted from them. And writs of intru≈øion were i≈ø≈øued out again≈øt Col. Shrimpton, Mr. Samuel Seawall, and we know not how many more be≈øides, that their lands might be taken from them under pretence of belonging to king James. An i≈øland in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of John Pittome antiently appropriated to the maintenance of a free-≈øchool, was in this way ≈øeized. How ≈øuch men can clear them≈øelves from the guilt of ≈øacrilegious Oppre≈ø≈øion, they had be≈øt con≈øider. Mr. Palmer ≈øwaggers and hectors at a ≈øtrange rate; for he hath the≈øe words, (p. 29.) We will produce tho≈øe that have ≈øaid (and ≈øworn) as much as all this comes to. For John Pittome hath upon oath declared, that James Sherlock, Sir Edmund's Sheriff, came on Dear I≈øland on the 28th of January 1688, and turned him and

Shrimpton and that the ≈øaid Sherlock put two men (whom he brought with him) into po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid I≈øland (as he ≈øaid) on behalf of King James the ≈øecond. Jeremiah Shepard aged forty two years and John Burrill aged fifty ≈øeven years, we who≈øe names are ≈øub≈øcribed being made choice of by the inhabitants of the town of Lynn in the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts colony in New-England to maintain their right to their properties and lands invaded by Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe governor, we do te≈øtify that (be≈øides Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe his unrea≈øonable demands of money by way of taxation, and that without an a≈ø≈øembly, and deputies ≈øent from our town according to ancient cu≈øtom, for the rai≈øing of money or levying of rates) our properties, our hone≈øt and ju≈øt and true titles to our land were al≈øo invaded, and particularly a great and con≈øiderable tract of land called by the name of the Nahants, the only ≈øecure place for the grazing of ≈øome thou≈øands of our ≈øheep, and without which our inhabitants could neither provide for their own families, nor be capacited to pay dues or duties for the maintenance of the publick, but (if di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of) the town mu≈øt needs be impoveri≈øhed, ruined, and rendered mi≈øerable, yet this very tract of land being petitioned for by Edward Randolph, was threatened to be rent out of our hands, notwith≈øtanding our hone≈øt and ju≈øt pleas for our right to the ≈øaid land, both by alienation of the ≈øaid land to us from the original proprietors the Natives, to whom we paid our monies by way of purcha≈øe, and notwith≈øtanding near fifty years peaceable and quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and improvement, and al≈øo inclo≈øure of the ≈øaid land by a ≈øtone wall, in which tract of land al≈øo two of our patentees were intere≈øted in common with us, viz. from the king, neither had any per≈øon a right to one foot of land in New-England by virtue of purcha≈øe, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion or grant of courts, but if we would have a≈ø≈øurance of our lands, we mu≈øt go to the king for it, and get patents of it. Finding no relief (and the governor having prohibited town-meetings, we earne≈øtly de≈øired liberty for our town to meet, to con≈øult what to do in ≈øo difficult a ca≈øe and exigency, but could not prevail. James Ru≈ø≈øell, E≈øq on the behalf of the proprietors of the ≈øtinted pa≈øture in Charle≈øtown, and on his own per≈øonal account, declares as followeth, viz.

That notwith≈øtanding the an≈øwer made to Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe, his demand by ≈øome gentlemen of Charle≈øtown on the behalf of the proprietors, which they judged ≈øatisfactory, or at lea≈øt they ≈øhould have a further hearing and opportunity to make out their rights, there was laid out to Mr. Lidget adjoining to his farm in Charle≈øtown a con≈øiderable tract of land (as it is ≈øaid one hundred and fifty acres) which was of con≈øiderable value, and did belong to divers per≈øons, which when it was laid out by Mr. Wells, there were divers bound-marks ≈øhewed by the proprietors, and ≈øome of them, and I had petitioned for a patent for my particular propriety, yet the whole tract was laid out to the ≈øaid Lidget, who not only did cut down wood thereon without the right owner's con≈øent, but arre≈øted ≈øome for

Had not an happy revolution happened in England, and ≈øo in New-England, in all probability tho≈øe few ill men would have ≈øqueezed more out of the poorer ≈øort of people there, than half their e≈øtates are worth, by forcing them to take patents. When ≈øome gentlemen in Bo≈øton re≈øolved in a legal way to defend their title to an i≈øland there, Sir Edmund's Attorney threatened that it might co≈øt them all that they are worth, and ≈øomething be≈øides, as appears by the following affidavit, viz.

The depo≈øition of Captain Daniel Turel, and Lieutenant Edward Willis, ≈øworn, ≈øay, That upon a Writ of Intru≈øion being ≈øerved on Deer-I≈øland, belonging to the town of Bo≈øton, and let unto Colonel Samuel Shrimpton by the ≈øelectmen of the ≈øaid town, the rent whereof being of long time appropriated towards the maintenance of a free ≈øchool in the town, we the deponents two of the ≈øelect-men of the ≈øaid town, do te≈øtify, That meeting with Mr. James Graham upon the town-hou≈øe, and telling him, that if Colonel Shrimpton did decline to per≈øonate the ca≈øe of the ≈øaid i≈øland, we the ≈øelect-men would. One of Sir Edmund's council and creatures, petitioned for an i≈øland belonging to the town of Plymouth, and becau≈øe the agents of the ≈øaid town obtained a voluntary ≈øub≈øcription from the per≈øons concerned to bear the charge of the ≈øuit; they were treated as criminals, and again≈øt all law, illegally compelled to an≈øwer in another county, and not that where the pretended mi≈ødemeanours were committed. And Mr. Wi≈øwall

A me≈ø≈øenger was ≈øent, to bring him to Bo≈øton on the 21≈øt June, 1688; he was then lame in both feet with the gout, fitter for a bed than a journey, therefore wrote to the governor, praying that he might be excu≈øed until he ≈øhould be able to travel, and engaged that then he would attend any court, but the next week the cruel officer by an expre≈øs order from Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe, forced him to ride in that condition, being ≈øhod with clouts in≈øtead of ≈øhoes; and when he came before the council he was there made to ≈øtand till the angui≈øh of his feet and ≈øhoulders had almo≈øt overcome him; after he was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed from the council, the me≈ø≈øenger came and told him, he mu≈øt go to goal, or enter into bonds for his appearance at the next ≈øuperior court held in Bo≈øton, and pay down 4 l. 2 s. in ≈øilver. After all this having been forced a third time out of his own county and colony, near forty miles, he was delivered from the hands and humours of his tyrannical oppre≈ø≈øors, who had expo≈øed him to great difficulties, charges, and to 228 miles travel in journeying to and from Bo≈øton, directly oppo≈øite to the place where he ought to have been tried, had he been guilty of any of the pretended mi≈ødemeanors, none of which his wor≈øt enemies ever had the face to read in open court, or openly to charge him with to this day. 7. As for Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe his ≈øupplying the Indians with amunition in the time of actual war with them, the following te≈øtimonies confirmed the people of New-England in the belief of it.

Lenox Beverley aged about twenty-five years being ≈øworn, ≈øaith, that he being ≈øoldier at Pemyquid the winter time 1688, where was Captain general Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe, knight, there came to the fort where Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe
then was, two ≈øquaws, the one Madocowandos's ≈øi≈øter, and the other Moxis's wife (as was ≈øaid) and two other Indian women that went along with them; they were in the fort with Sir Edmund two days, and when they came forth they ≈øeemed to be half drunk, this deponent and Peter Ripley was commanded to guard the≈øe ≈øquaws from Pemyquid to New-Harbour, being in di≈øtance about two miles, and as we pa≈ø≈øed on the way Madocowandos's ≈øi≈øter laid down her burden in the ≈ønow and commanded the deponant to take it up, whereupon the deponant looked into the ba≈øket, and ≈øaw a ≈ømall bag which he opened, and found it to be gun-powder, which „Äà‚óä„Äâ judged five pounds weight, and a bag of bullets of a greater weight, and the weight of the ba≈øket I took up, was as much as the deponant could well carry along, and the other three ≈øquaws had each one of them their ba≈økets, which appeared rather to be of greater than le≈ø≈øer burden, than that the deponant carried, which were all of them loaden, and brought out of the fort, and Madocowandos's ≈øi≈øter ≈øaid ≈øhe had that powder of Sir Edmund, and added, that ≈øhe was to come again to him within four days.

That the Indians declared they were encouraged by Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe to make war upon the Engli≈øh, is mo≈øt certainly true, although the lying author of that ≈øcandalous pamphlet, called New-England's faction di≈øcovered, has the impudence to ≈øay, that it is certainly fal≈øe. Roche≈øter in the king's province, Sept. 16, 1688. That when the Engli≈øh ≈øecured ≈øome of the Indians mentioned, and brought them before Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe's ju≈øtices, they were ba≈øely and barbarou≈øly u≈øed for their pains, the following affidavits ≈øhew.

Sudbury in New-England, March 22, 1688-9, Thomas Browne, aged about forty-four years, and John Goodenow, aged about fifty-four years, John Growt, ≈øenior, aged near ≈øeventy years, Jacob Moore, aged about forty-four years, Jonathan Stanhope, aged about fifty-≈øeven years, and John

Thomas Browne and John Goodenow, two of the ≈øub≈øcribers above, having received this declaration from John James the Indian, we thought it our duty forthwith to inform authority, and did with the Indian pre≈øently go to Watertown to ju≈øtice Bond, where the ≈øaid John James did voluntarily give his te≈øtimony before the ≈øaid ju≈øtice Bond, which after he had taken, the ≈øaid ju≈øtice Bond ordered us the ≈øaid Thomas Browne and John Goodenow to make our appearance before the governor Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe, or one of the council with the Indian, which accordingly we did, when we came to the governor's hou≈øe; after long waiting in a very wet and cold ≈øea≈øon we were admitted unto the governor's pre≈øence, where we were detained until eleven or twelve o'clock at night, and after a very unkind treat, we humbly prayed his excellency, he would plea≈øe to di≈øcharge us of the Indian, but he told us no, and joaked us, ≈øaying, we were a couple of brave men, and had the command, one of a troop of hor≈øe, and the other a company of foot, and could we not know what to do with a poor Indian? Further, he a≈øked us what money we gave the Indian to tell us ≈øuch news, and commanded us ≈øtill to take care of the Indian till his plea≈øure was to call for us again, and this as we would an≈øwer it. Thus being ≈øeverely chidden out of his pre≈øence, we were forced with the Indian to ≈øeek our quarters where we could find them. The next morning
we were preparing to go home again to Sudbury (being twenty miles or more) being Saturday, we were again ≈øent for by the governor, by a me≈ø≈øenger, to wait on the governor, with the Indian, which we did, and waited at the exchange or council-hou≈øe in Bo≈øton, from nine o'clock in the morning till three of the clock in the afternoon, where in the face of the country we were made to wait upon the Indian with many ≈øquibs and ≈øcoffs that me met withal; at la≈øt we were commanded up before the governor and his council, where we were examined apart over and over, and about the ≈øun-≈øetting were granted leave to go home, it being the evening before the Sabbath.

On Monday morning following, being the 25th of March, 1689, Jacob Moore, Jo≈øeph Graves, Jo≈øeph Curtis, Jo≈øeph Moore, Obadiah Ward, were by Thomas Larkin as a me≈ø≈øenger fetched down to Bo≈øton, where after examination, Jacob Moore was committed to clo≈øe pri≈øon. Jo≈øeph Moore, Jo≈øeph Graves, Jo≈øeph Curtis, and Obadiah Ward were ≈øent home again, paying the ≈øaid Larkin twelve ≈øhillings per man. On the next Monday morning after, being the fir≈øt day of April 1689, Samuel Gookin the ≈øheriff of Middle≈øex and his deputy came up to Sudbury, and commanded Thomas Browne, John Goodenow ≈øenior, John Growt ≈øenior, Jonathan Stanhope, John Parmiter, forthwith to appear at Bo≈øton, at Colonel Page's hou≈øe, but it being a wet and cold day, we were detained at judge Dudley's hou≈øe at Roxbury, where after long waiting, had the kindne≈øs ≈øhewn us, to have an examination every man apart before judge Dudley, judge Stoughton, Mr. Graham and others, and were bound over to an≈øwer at the next ≈øuperiour court to be held at Bo≈øton, what ≈øhould there be objected again≈øt us upon his maje≈øty's account. Thomas Browne, John Goodenow, ≈øenior, John Growt, ≈øenior, were each of them bound over in three hundred pound bonds, and each man two ≈øureties in three hundred pound bond a piece. John Parmiter and Jonathan Stanhope, were bound in a hundred pound a piece, be≈øides the lo≈øs of our time and hindrance of our bu≈øine≈øs, the reproach and ignominy of bond and impri≈øonment, we ≈øhall only take the boldne≈øs to give a true account of what money we were forced to expend out of our own pur≈øes as followeth, to the ≈øheriff, and other nece≈ø≈øary charges.

Although no man does accu≈øe Sir Edmund meerly upon Indian te≈øtimony, yet let it be duly weighed (the premi≈øes con≈øidered) whether it might not create ≈øu≈øpicion and an a≈øtoni≈øhment in the people of New-England, in that he did not puni≈øh the Indians who thus charged him, but the Engli≈øh who complained of them for it. And it is certain, that ≈øome very good and wi≈øe men in New-England do verily believe that he was deeply guilty in this matter, e≈øpecially con≈øidering what might pa≈øs between him and Hope Hood an Indian, concerning which Mr. Thomas Danforth the pre≈øent deputy-governor at Bo≈øton in New-England, in a letter bearing date April 1, 1690, writeth thus:‚Äî

The commander in chief of tho≈øe that made this ≈øpoil, (i. e.) the ≈øpoil which was made in the province of Maine on the 18th of March la≈øt, is Hope Hood an Indian, one that was with ≈øundry other Indians in the ≈øummer 1688 ≈øeized by ≈øome of Sir Edmund's ju≈øtices and commanders in the province of Maine, and ≈øent pri≈øoners to Bo≈øton, Sir Edmund being then at the we≈øtward, where he continued ab≈øent many weeks; upon his return finding the Indians in pri≈øon, fell into a great rage again≈øt tho≈øe gentlemen that had acted therein, declared his re≈øolution to ≈øet them at liberty and calling his council together, was by ≈øome oppo≈øed therein, and among others, one gentleman of the council accu≈øed this Hope Hood to be a bloody rogue, and added, that he, the ≈øaid Hope Hood, had threatened his life, and therefore prayed Sir Edmund that he might not be enlarged, but Sir Edmund made a flout and ≈øcorn of all that could be ≈øaid. At the ≈øame time ≈øome of the council
de≈øired Sir Edmund that this Hope Hood might be ≈øent for before the council, to which he replied, that he never had had a quarter of an hour's conference with any of them, and that he ≈øcorned to di≈øcour≈øe with any heathen of them all, yet all this notwith≈øtanding, at the ≈øame time whil≈øt the council was thus met, did Sir Edmund privately withdraw him≈øelf, and repair to the pri≈øon where this Hope Hood was pri≈øoner, and did there continue with him two or three hours in private, the truth of what is above related is atte≈øted by ≈øundry gentlemen that were of Edmund's council, and were then ear witne≈ø≈øes, and likewi≈øe by others that ≈øaw Sir Edmund at the pri≈øon; and as it is now verily believed that at that very time he con≈øulted the mi≈øchief that is now acted by the ≈øaid Hope Hood and company. Thus Mr. Danforth.

9. That Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe di≈øcountenanced making defence again≈øt the Indians, is complained of by five gentlemen who were of his council, and much concerned at his ≈øtrange actings in that matter as in the account annexed to this apology is to be ≈øeen. It is al≈øo confirmed by the Affidavits of two hone≈øt men, viz.

Henry Kerley aged about fifty-≈øeven years and Thomas How aged thirty-five years or thereabouts, both inhabitants of the town of Marlborough, do both te≈øtify that in the fall of the year, 1688, when Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe came from New-York to Bo≈øton ≈øometime after the Indians had killed ≈øome Engli≈øhmen at North-field in New-England, coming through our town of Marlborough, the ≈øaid Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe examined this deponent Henry Kerley by what order we did fortify and garri≈øon our hou≈øes, I an≈øwered it was by order of Captain Nichol≈øon, the ≈øaid Sir Edmund then ≈øaid, he had no power ≈øo to do. He the ≈øaid Sir Edmund examined what arms we made u≈øe of, and carried with us on the watch, and what charge was given us, an≈øwer was made by the deponant, they carried fire arms, and the charge was to keep a true watch, to examine all we met with, and ≈øecure ≈øu≈øpicious per≈øons that we met with, the ≈øaid Sir Edmund ≈øaid, what if they will not be ≈øecured, and what if you ≈øhould kill them; an≈øwer was made by the deponant, that if we ≈øhould kill them, we were in our way, then Mr. Randolph being there in the company ≈øaid, you are in the way to be hanged. Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe ≈øaid further, that tho≈øe per≈øons that had left their hou≈øes, to
dwell in garri≈øons, if they would not return, others ≈øhould be put in that would live there.

div.p: That Sir Edmund's high ≈øheriff was a ≈øtranger in the country, and one that had no e≈øtate there needs no proof, and that ≈øtrangers who had no freehold, were impannelled for Jurors is notoriou≈øly known. So it was in the ca≈øe of the Ip≈øwichmen as hath been noted, and when that reverend per≈øon Mr. Charles Morton, was cau≈øele≈øly and maliciou≈øly pro≈øecuted, he was not only compelled to an≈øwer (contrary to law) in another county, and not in that wherein the good ≈øermon they found fault with, was preached, but that if po≈ø≈øible, they might give him a blow, there was ≈øummoned to ≈øerve as a jury man, one John Gib≈øon no hou≈øholder nor of any e≈øtate or credit, and one John Leving≈øworth a brick-layer, who lived in another colony two hundred miles di≈øtance. When tho≈øe in government will u≈øe ≈øuch ba≈øe artifices as the≈øe to accompli≈øh their pernicious de≈øigns, how ≈øhould any man's e≈øtate or life be ≈øecure under him?

11. That the per≈øons objected again≈øt, were ≈øome of them guilty of great extortion is manife≈øt from what has been related, and may yet be further proved, for (as by ≈øome in≈øtances we have already ≈øeen, and ≈øhall now hear more) they compelled men to take patents for their own lands, which they and their fathers before them, had quietly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed till the≈øe covetous creatures became a nu≈øance to the country, and it may be, none more criminal, as to this particular, than Mr. Palmer and Mr. We≈øt. A friend of their own, viz. Mr. Randolph, does in ≈øeveral of his Letters bitterly complain of them upon this account. In a letter of his of Augu≈øt the 25th, 1687, he writeth thus:

I believe all the inhabitants in Bo≈øton will be forced to take grants and conformations of their lands, as now intended, the inhabitants of the province of Maine which will bring in va≈øt profits to Mr. We≈øt, he taking what fees he plea≈øes to demand. I ≈øhall always have a due honour and re≈øpect for his excellency, but I mu≈øt buy his favour at three or four hundred pounds a year lo≈øs. And in another to
the ≈øame, June, 21, 1688, he hath the≈øe words. I went to one Shurte town-clerk of Pemyquid, to know what lea≈øes were made lately, and by whom, and for what quit rent, he told me that above a year ago Captain Palmer, and Mr. We≈øt produced to them a commi≈ø≈øion from Colonel Dungan, to di≈øpo≈øe of all their lands to whoever would take lea≈øes at five ≈øhillings the hundred acres quit rent. They let there and at a place called Dartmouth twelve or ≈øixteen miles di≈øtant from Pemyquid about one hundred and forty lea≈øes, ≈øome had eight hundred or ten hundred acres, few le≈øs than a hundred, ≈øome but three or four acres and all paid 2l. 10s. for pa≈ø≈øing their grants of 100 acres of woodland, with twenty acres of mar≈øh where-ever it could be found, but this bred a great mi≈øchief among the people; few or none have their lands mea≈øured or marked, they were in ha≈øte, and got what they could, they had their emi≈ø≈øaries among the poor people, and frighted them to take grants, ≈øome come and complained to the governor, and prayed him to confirm their rights which he refu≈øed to do, the commi≈ø≈øion and whole proceeding being illegal, having notice they were to be under his government, they re≈øented it, but ≈øerved their turn. The poor have been very much oppre≈ø≈øed here, the fort run all to ruin, and wants a great deal to repair it. Captain Palmer and Mr. We≈øt laid out for them≈øelves ≈øuch large lots, and Mr. Graham though not there, had a child's portion, I think ≈øome have eight thou≈øand or ten thou≈øand acres. I hear not of one penny rent comming in to the king, from them who have their grants confirmed at York. and the five ≈øhillings an hundred acres was only a ≈øham upon the people: at our return we ≈øaw very good land at Winter Harbour, enough to make large ≈øettlements for many people. The governor will have it fir≈øt mea≈øured, and then ≈øurveyed, and then will di≈øpo≈øe of it for ≈øettlements, Mr. Graham and his family are ≈øettled at Bo≈øton, he is made Attorney general, and now the governer is ≈øafe in his New-York Confidents, all others being ≈øtrangers, to his council. 'Twas not well done of Palmer and We≈øt to tear all in peices that was ≈øettled and granted at Pemyquid by Sir Edmund, that was the ≈øeene where they placed and di≈øplaced at plea≈øure and were as arbitary as the great Turk. Some of the fir≈øt ≈øettlers of that ea≈øtern country were denied grants of their own lands, whil≈øt tho≈øe men have given the improved lands among≈øt them≈øelves, of which I ≈øuppo≈øe Mr. Hutchin≈øon hath complained. In another, May the 10th 1689, he ≈øays; I mu≈øt confe≈øs there have been ill men from
New-York, who have too much ≈øtudied the di≈øea≈øe of this people, and both in courts and councils, they have not been treated well. Thus does Edward Randolph, a bird of the ≈øame feather with them≈øelves confe≈øs the truth, as to this matter, concerning his brother Palmer and We≈øt.

And that oppre≈ø≈øive fees have been extorted by indigent and exacting officers is declared by Mr. Hinckley the pre≈øent governor of New-Plymouth in his narrative of the grievances and oppre≈ø≈øions of their maje≈øties good ≈øubjects in the colony of New-Plymouth in New-England, by the illegal and arbitrary actings in the late Government under Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe, which narrative is too large to be here in≈øerted, but it is po≈ø≈øible it may be publi≈øhed by it≈øelf, whereby it will appear that every corner in the country did ring with complaints of the oppre≈ø≈øions, and (to ≈øpeak in Mr. Palmer's phra≈øe) horrible u≈øages of the≈øe ill men. Some pa≈ø≈øages out of Mr. Hinckley's narrative re≈øpecting this matter, we ≈øhall here tran≈øcribe, who≈øe words are the≈øe which follow.

The bill of co≈øt taxed by judge Palmer ≈øeems al≈øo to be the greate≈øt extortion ever heard of before, as thrice twenty ≈øhillings for three motions for judgment at the ≈øame term, (and was it not their courte≈øy they did not move ten times one after another at the ≈øame rate) and taxed al≈øo, five pound for the king's attorney, and one and twenty ≈øhillings for the judges, and ten ≈øhillings for the ≈øheriff, and other particulars as by the ≈øaid bill appeareth, and that which makes it the greater extortion is, that the whole bill of co≈øt was exacted of every one of them, which each of them mu≈øt pay down, or be kept pri≈øoners till they did, though all ≈øeven of them were jointly informed again≈øt in one information. Thus Mr. Hinckley.

The cry of poor widows and fatherle≈øs is gone up to heaven again≈øt them on this account; for the probate of a will and letter of admini≈øtration above fifty ≈øhillings hath been extorted out of the hands of the poor, nay they have been ≈øometimes forced to pay more than four pounds, when not much above a crown had been due. Let Andrew Sergeant and Jo≈øeph Quilter among many others ≈øpeak if this be not true, who were compelled to travel two hundred miles for the probate of a will, and to pay the unrea≈øonable and oppre≈ø≈øive fees complained of.

Be≈øides the≈øe things, under Sir Edmund's government they had wicked ways to extort money when they plea≈øed. Mr. William Coleman complains (and hath given his oath accordingly) that upon the ≈øuppo≈øed hired evidence of one man he ≈øu≈øtained
forty pounds damage in his e≈øtate. And there were complaints all over the country that Sir Edmund's exci≈øe men would pretend ≈øickne≈øs on the road, and get a cup of drink of the ho≈øpitable people, but privately drop a piece of money, and afterwards make oath that they bought drink at tho≈øe hou≈øes, for which the innocent per≈øons were fined mo≈øt unrea≈øonably, and which was extorted from them, though the≈øe villanies were declared and made known to tho≈øe then in power. William Goodhue, and Mary Dennis might be produced as witne≈øs hereof, with many more. Some of Sir Edmund's creatures have ≈øaid, that ≈øuch things as the≈øe made his government to ≈øtink. Al≈øo John Hovey and others complain of ≈øu≈øtaining ten pounds damages by the extortion of officers, though never any thing (they could hear of) was charged upon them to this day, John and Chri≈øtoper O≈øgood complain of their being ≈øent to pri≈øon nine or ten days, without a mittimus, or any thing laid to their charge, and that afterwards they were forced to pay exce≈ø≈øive charges‚ÄîIt would fill a volume, if we ≈øhould produce and in≈øert all the affidavits which do confirm the truth of the≈øe complaints.

In the time of that unhappy government, if the officers wanted money, it was but ≈øeizing and impri≈øoning the be≈øt men in the country for no fault in the world, and the greedy officers would hereby have gri≈øt to their mill. Thus was Major Appleton dealt with. Thus Captain Brad≈øtreet. Thus that worthy and wor≈øhipful gentleman Nathaniel Sal≈øtori≈øtal, E≈øquire, was ≈øerved by them and barbarou≈øly pro≈øecuted, without any information or crime laid to his charge; for he had done nothing worthy of bonds, but it was the plea≈øure of Sir Edmund and ≈øome others, thus to abu≈øe a gentleman far more honourably de≈øcended than him≈øelf, and one concerned in the government of New-England before him, but (to his eternal renown) one who refu≈øed to accept of an illegal and arbitrary commi≈ø≈øion, when in the reign of the late king James it was offered to him.

We have now ≈øeen a whole jury of complaints which concur in their verdict again≈øt Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe and his confederates. Were the≈øe things to be heard upon the place, where the witne≈ø≈øes who gave in their affidavits are re≈øident, they would amount to legal proof, as to every particular which was by the agents of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts colony in New-England objected again≈øt Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe, and others ≈øeized and ≈øecured by the people there.

Moreover there are other matters referring to Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe which cau≈øed great, and almo≈øt univer≈øal jealou≈øy of
him. For fir≈øt, His commi≈ø≈øion was ≈øuch as would make any one believe that a courtier in the time of the late king James ≈øpoke true, who ≈øaid Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe was ≈øent to New-England on purpo≈øe to be a plague to the people there. For he with three or four more, none of them cho≈øen by the people, but rather by that implacable enemy who pro≈øceuted the quo warranto's again≈øt their charters, had power given them to make laws, and rai≈øe what monies they ≈øhould think meet for the ≈øupport of their own government, and he had power him≈øelf alone to ≈øend the be≈øt and mo≈øt u≈øeful men a thou≈øand miles, (and further if he would) out of the country, and to build cities and ca≈øtles (in the air if he could) and demoli≈øh them again, and make the pur≈øes of the poor people pay for it all. Such a commi≈ø≈øion was an un≈øufferable grievance, and no hone≈øt Engli≈øhman would ever have accepted of it, or acted by it.

Secondly, Jealou≈øies were augumented by his involving the country in a war with the Indians, by means whereof he hath occa≈øioned the ruin of many families and plantations; yea the death or captivity of we know not how many ≈øouls. For he went (with the Ro≈øe frigate, and violently ≈øeized, and took and carried away, in a time of peace all the hou≈øhold goods and merchandi≈øes of mon≈øieur Cakeen a Frenchman at Penob≈øcot who was allied to the Indians having married the daughter of one of their princes whom they call Sagamores or Sachems; and when this was done, it was ea≈øy to fore≈øee, and was generally concluded that the French and Indians would ≈øoon be upon the Engli≈øh, as it quickly came to pa≈øs. After the flame was kindled, and barbarous outrages commited by the Indians, Sir Edmund's managery was ≈øuch as filled the country with greater fears of an horrid de≈øign. For bloody Indians whom the Engli≈øh had ≈øecured, were not only di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, but rather courted than puni≈øhed by him.

Thirdly, It cannot be expre≈øt what ju≈øt and amazing fears ≈øurprized the people of New-England when they had notice of the late king James being in France, le≈øt Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe who≈øe governor and confident he was, ≈øhould betray them into the power of the French king, other circum≈øtances concurring to ≈øtrenghen the≈øe fears. The Mohawks and other Indians were in ho≈øtility again≈øt the French and it was very advantagious to the Engli≈øh intere≈øt to have it ≈øo, but Sir Edmund cau≈øed them to make a peace with the French, whereby the French intere≈øt in tho≈øe parts was ≈øtrengthened, and the Engli≈øh weakened. Mr. Peter Reverdy (a French prote≈øtant) in his memoirs concerning Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe complains of this.

After that Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe and his accomplices were ≈øecured, ≈øuch reports and informations came to hand, as made New-England admire the divine providence in accompli≈øhing what was done again≈øt the late oppre≈ø≈øors. They then ≈øaw the per≈øons from whom they ≈øu≈øpected the greate≈øt danger, were now incapable of betraying them.

If an unaccountable in≈øtinct and re≈øolution had not animated the inhabitants in and about Bo≈øton, to ≈øeize on tho≈øe few men, the people there believe New-England would have been in the hands not of king William but king Lewis e'er this day: For in Sept. 1689, ≈øeveral ve≈ø≈øels belonging to New-England were taken near Can≈øoe in America by ≈øome French men of war. The pri≈øoners ≈øince at liberty, inform, that the French told them, that there was a fleet of ≈øhips bound from France directly for Bo≈øton in New-England, but ≈øome of them were taken by the Engli≈øh ≈øhips of war, and three or four of them lo≈øt at Newfoundland, and that Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe had ≈øent to the French king for them to come over, and the country ≈øhould be delivered up. And the Lieutenant of a French man of war profe≈ø≈øed, that if Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe had not been impri≈øoned, they would then have gone to Bo≈øton. This ≈øhews what a good opinion the French had of him, and ≈øuch reports ≈øo te≈øtified made a ≈øtrange impre≈ø≈øion on the ≈øpirits of the people throughout the country: And that the world may ≈øee we do not write fictions of our own, the ≈øub≈øequent Affidavits are produced and here in≈øerted.

John Langford of Salem te≈øtifieth, That he being in the Ketch Margaret of Salem, Daniel Gygles commander, they were taken by the French ≈øhips off Tarbay in America, near Can≈øoe on Tue≈øday the 17th day of September la≈øt pa≈øt, and being put on board the Admiral, viz. The Lumbu≈øcado, and in the ≈øaid ≈øhip carried a pri≈øoner to Port-Royal, and then did hear ≈øeveral of the company on board the ≈øaid ≈øhip ≈øay, that they came directly from France, and that there was ten or twelve ≈øail of them ≈øhips of war that came in company together, but ≈øome of them were taken upon the coa≈øt of France and ≈øome were lo≈øt ≈øince, and that they were all bound directly for New-England, and that Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe late governor of New-England had ≈øent to the French king for them to come over, and the country ≈øhould be delivered up into his hands, and that they expected that before they ≈øhould arrive, it would have been delivered into the hands of the French.

Benjamin Majery of Salem, Jer≈øey-man, al≈øo te≈øtifieth, that he being taken the ≈øame day, and at the ≈øame place in the Ketch Diligence, Gilbert Peters commander; as is above≈øaid in the evidence of John Langford, he heard the ≈øame related, by ≈øeveral of the company on board the other French ≈øhip of war that was in company with the Lumbu≈øcado; viz. The Frugum, ≈øo called, that there was ten ≈øail of them came out directly from France together; that Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe late governor of New-England had ≈øent to the king of France for them to come over, and he would deliver the country into their hands, and that they were bound directly for Bo≈øton in New-England but had lo≈øt mo≈øt of their ≈øhips coming over.

div.p: John Langford and Benjamin Magery, both made oath to the truth of their re≈øpective evidences in Salem, November 23, 1689.

Jo≈øhua Conant te≈øtifieth, That he being commander of the Ketch, Thomas and Mary of Salem, he was taken by three French ≈øhips off from Tarbay, near Can≈øoe, upon Tue≈øday the 17th of September la≈øt, two of which were ≈øhips of war, the other a merchant-man, and being put on board the Admiral, viz. the Lumbu≈øcado, and therein carried to to Port-Royal a pri≈øoner, Mr. Mero told me that the French on board told him, that there was ten ≈øail of them ≈øhips of war came out in company together from France, and that they came directly from France, and were bound to Bo≈øton in New-England, and that Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe had ≈øent to the French king for them, and that the country was to be delivered up into their hands; but having lo≈øt ≈øeveral of their ≈øhips in their voyage, and hearing that Sir Edmund Andro≈ø≈øe was taken, and now in hold, ≈øhould not proceed at pre≈øent, but threatened what they would do the next ≈øummer.
